title: Under Wild Skies Sues National Rifle Association
text:
National Rifle Association CEO Wayne LaPierre, his wife and other top NRA officials were treated to free hunting safaris to exotic locales by an NRA vendor, according to a new lawsuit that raises new questions about the organization’s governance.

The lawsuit was filed Wednesday in Circuit Court in Fairfax, Va., by Under Wild Skies Inc., which has produced a TV hunting program for many years. The producer claims the NRA owes it $17.1 million for breach of contract after the gun-rights group stopped paying agreed-upon fees to sponsor the program and advertise on it.

Under Wild Skies is hosted by Tony Makris, who also is a top executive at the NRA’s former advertising firm, Ackerman McQueen Inc. The NRA and Ackerman McQueen have fallen out and are embroiled in other litigation. Mr. Makris declined to comment, as did a spokesman for Ackerman McQueen.

Under Wild Skies says it is being unfairly punished by the NRA as retaliation for the group’s dispute with Ackerman McQueen, adding that “UWS is not a subsidiary of Ackerman McQueen and is not under its control or direction.”

William A. Brewer III, an attorney for the NRA, called the lawsuit “without merit” and a desperate attempt by Under Wild Skies to avoid answering basic questions about its performance under the production company’s NRA contract.

As for allegations that NRA representatives participated in free hunting safaris, Mr. Brewer said: “These were trips to extol the benefits of hunting and promote the brand of the NRA with one of its core audience groups. The NRA’s past support of this show was public and widely known.”

In the lawsuit, Under Wild Skies said “prominent NRA figures,” including Mr. LaPierre and his wife, had appeared in hunts on the TV show, and that “UWS paid for the safaris and hunts of these NRA officers, spouses and board members.” Among the locations for these hunts, the suit alleged, were Botswana, Tanzania, Mozambique and Uruguay.

The NRA officials used their experiences on the program to seek memberships into elite hunting organizations, the complaint alleged.

The NRA also received benefits from the officials’ appearances on the show, the suit said, including brand awareness in the hunting community and donations from hunting groups.

The plaintiff included copies of a 2016 contract extending the NRA’s sponsorship of the program until 2025, signed by Mr. LaPierre.

The allegation that Mr. LaPierre and other NRA figures received free safari hunts is the latest revelation to buffet the organization in recent months. Mr. LaPierre allegedly received more than $540,000 of travel and wardrobe expenses billed to Ackerman McQueen, and the NRA last year was negotiating to buy its CEO a $6 million mansion in an arrangement involving the ad agency that later fell apart.

NRA officials have said Mr. LaPierre’s travel and wardrobe costs were justified as business expenses, and that no NRA money was spent on the aborted house-purchase proposal. Mr. LaPierre so far has prevailed in internal boardroom battles over the expense allegations and appears to have the support of most NRA board members.

Under Wild Skies said the NRA stopped paying it after sending a letter in July demanding “excessive information” about the show and its metrics.

Write to Mark Maremont at mark.maremont@wsj.com
description: National Rifle Association CEO Wayne LaPierre, his wife and other top NRA officials were treated to free hunting safaris by an NRA vendor, according to a new lawsuit that raises new questions about the organization’s governance.
